meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, so people can probably continue to write down their questions as as we go on in our discussion. But would anybody like to start? Actually maybe yeah, would anybody like to volunteer a particular question?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gulcin Pekkurnaz
meeting_annotations.transcript: I can start because I don't work on phase separation. We're stumbled upon something I'm trying to even understand whether it's a phase separation or but one question I have, how many phases or how do we know what one phase is different than another? What like how many phases and how do we define that? And what distinguishes one phase from another? Are there any classifications in the field? We talked about

meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Those of you who work on this, any any suggestions there?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jan Spille
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think so I would go first too so I can focus on the writing as well. And also because that's exactly what what we're thinking about. So what we're I think starting to see or going to start seeing is that there is so much complexity in this whole phase separation field. It's not just a liquid and a liquid. So so what we're thinking about is how do complex multi-phase assemblies arise from from complex systems that you have in the cell as compared to your simple reconstitution systems where you have maybe one, two, three components but in the cell you have dozens. So there are certainly many phases. You can think about material properties I would say. You can have several liquid phases that that coexist but that have different composition and are therefore different phases. But they can also have different material properties like more gel-like, more glass-like or liquid-like. Maybe at some point it transitions into a stable aggregate then the question is is that still what we're talking about or what do we not care about that because it is a stable assembly and there are no dynamics for example.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think it's very interesting and helpful. Does anybody else have anything they want to add to that?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Seth Childers
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'd just like to add about the the idea of different biomolecular condensates with different compositions and then that leads to the question of what are the rules of demixing of different phase separated structures. So if you have a biomolecular condensate that's involved in RNA biochemistry versus one that's involved in metabolism or different cellular processes like what if you look at those sequences what about them causes them to to phase separate from one another or to demix into distinct states. I feel like understanding those rules will be important moving forward.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Zid
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I have a question maybe the bacteria. Are there phase separated or condensates that don't have nucleic acids? I know that like in vitro you can make them but in vivo do we find condensates that don't have nucleic acids or are they kind of a universal in vivo and again I think this multivalency it makes sense they're these super repetitive low information and so it makes sense that they would be in there but are there non-nucleic acid phase separated

meeting_annotations.speaker: Seth Childers
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah and in at least in bacteria there there are condensates that largely co-localize signaling pathways that have a scaffolding protein that is the principal protein that phase separates. This is a protein called PopZ in Caulobacter and then they recruit a set of histidine kinases.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Zid
meeting_annotations.transcript: And nucleic acids are excluded from there?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Seth Childers
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, that's very interesting. So somebody else have a question that they would like to throw out for the group?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Grace Stokes
meeting_annotations.transcript: I have a molecular like a very detailed question about thermodynamics. Usually my background is kind of studying how different phases in a homogeneous system like you can calculate the changes in energy from one phase to another when you have to transition between phases but it sounds like phase separated systems in biology are very complex and heterogeneous and it's not is it possible to get thermodynamic information as they change phases?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's an excellent question. So can anybody provide insight here?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jan Spille
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes. I would say it depends. It depends on your system. We we have investigated one system in the past where we were able to describe a very simple free energy function just say we have a a bulk term and a surface term and from that we can derive a condensate size distribution. And really just those two terms so just two constants, two interaction energies that describe the distribution of condensate sizes that we find. But I don't think that's going to be universally true. I think in most scenarios it's probably going to be more complex than that. That's at least my take.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Actually another thermodynamic really related question that I guess I have had is many of these structures seem to be equilibrium structures but are some of them steady state structures so that there's actively energy involved in maintaining the structure? Does anybody have any information on that one? I I'm quite curious about that. Again working on the cytoskeleton right things like microtubules need energy to be polymerized and I'm wondering if there are any of these phase separated structures that are similarly energy utilizing.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Seth Childers
meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess in bacterial examples which are probably not the norm because this has been more studied in eukaryotes but one of them is this protein that's involved in chromosome segregation. It's a CTPase so its ability to bind to DNA and then subsequently spread is dependent upon CTP hydrolysis. And then this is I don't know if you classify this as energy but it's sort of fuel-like in that the degradosome which which forms the bacterial degradosome RNC it it forms phase separated structures in bacteria that are dependent upon RNA. So when substrate's there it forms a condensate when it consumes the substrate those condensates dissolve. So if you call that energy but it's requires input.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Zid
meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess a question that I had is to me a lot of this formation of condensates makes sense because again like if you have usually RNAs are covered with ribosomes plowing through and then you have stress and you have these free RNAs and so now you have these multivalent substrates for things to bind but then the dissolution doesn't seem like that seems much harder and I'm wondering how much more energy comes in and I know that a lot of ATPases are important for the dissolution of these granules and so I wonder if the dissolution might be you need more energy going in than the formation which is energetically favorable. Because you can't just get ribosomes in there to start translating and kicking things off.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Actually there is a real analogy there to the cytoskeleton right? In that in fact microtubules the energy is not used to build them the energy is used to blow it up. So I think that that's a is a very interesting point.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Other people's comments either on this or other questions that they would like the group to consider?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jan Spille
meeting_annotations.transcript: So so I think there's also an analogy in the in the cell nucleus. The the condensates that we're thinking about are related to transcription and of course there's chromatin everywhere and you have active chromatin remodeling motors or enzymes ATP consuming proteins but when you delete some of them some of these condensates seem to collapse into into larger structures. So the activity might again be something that that pulls them apart or creates separation, fission, whatever it is.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Holly Goodson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Other other questions from people especially people we haven't heard from like Yan or Chiming?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yan Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I have a so a question that really interests me is to relate the dynamics of the phase separation with the you know the time scale of cell signaling. So a question that I find really interesting is by what mechanism do those you know does the separation phase separation occur fast enough to accommodate the you know the rapid dynamics and interaction needed for the cell signaling because the cell signaling is very transient and involves like very rapid and dynamic I guess sometimes exchange of contents right the signaling
